title: Welcome to my website!
text:
LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Email
  




Welcome to my website!

Yaʼátʼééh! Shí éí Leah Nez yinishyé. Áshiihí nishłį́, Tábąąhá bashishchíín, Bitʼą́ą́nii dashicheii, dóó Táchiiʼnii dashinalí. Ákótʼéego Diné asdzáán nishłį́. Cleveland di shighan.



Hello, my name is Leah Nez! I was born of the Salt Clan and born for the Water Edge People. My maternal grandfather is of the Under His Cover Clan and my paternal grandfather is of the Red Running into the Water People. In this way, I am a Navajo woman. I am currently living in Cleveland.


I am a PhD student in Bioethics & Health Humanities at Case Western Reserve University and a T32 Scholar in the CTSC. My work focuses on community-based research, and ethical frameworks in genomics and public health with Indigenous communities. I am currently involved in projects centered on culturally informed genomics education materials and participatory research methods for further understanding what community members want from genomics research.
On this website, you will find my published work. You will also find news about my current research projects, as well as information on upcoming events and conferences where I will be speaking. Please look around and hopefully we can stay in contact!
Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like to discuss any potential projects.

title: Education and Training
text:
CWRU Bioethics | Google Scholar
I am a PhD student in Bioethics & Health Humanities at Case Western Reserve University. My doctoral training emphasizes interdisciplinary approaches to ethical questions in medicine, public health, and the life sciences. Through coursework and research, I focus on community-engaged methods, Indigenous-centered ethical frameworks, and social justice–oriented approaches to bioethical inquiry.

title: Education and Training
text:
T32 Predoctoral Scholar
2025 T32 Predoc Cohort
I am an NIH-funded T32 Predoctoral Scholar, receiving specialized research training alongside my doctoral studies. This program supports interdisciplinary training in health-related research, with an emphasis on mentorship, methodological development, and responsible research practices. My T32 training complements my broader research interests in genomics, public health ethics, and community-engaged scholarship.

title: Education and Training
text:
Justice Dialogues Scholar
Justice Dialogues Website
As a Justice Dialogues Scholar, I have participated in training focused on ethical dialogue, equity, and engagement across difference. This program emphasizes reflective practice, communication, and justice-oriented approaches to scholarly and professional work. My participation informs how I approach collaborative research, community engagement, and ethical deliberation in academic and public settings.

title: Education and Training
text:
SING Instructor
I serve as an instructor with the Summer Internship for Indigenous Peoples in Genomics (SING), the U.S.-based program dedicated to training Indigenous students and community members in genomics techniques and ethical research practices.

title: Professional Experiences
text:
I have worked in research as an intern or assistant in various labs and offices. These roles have grounded me in community-engaged, qualitative, and ethics-focused work that directly informs my current PhD training in bioethics and health humanities.

Summer Research Assistant
Maxwell J. Mehlman, JD
Case Western Reserve University
Kim Kaphingst, ScD
University of Utah
In this role, I worked for a collaborative project between Case Western Reserve University and the University of Utah. My work has included conducting individual interviews with participants and helping to develop the codebook for qualitative analysis. This work deepened my thinking about nudging in research ethics and how to think through those considerations in my future work.



Professional Research Assistant
Katrina G. Claw, PhD
University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus
Working with Dr. Claw, I contribute to genomics and bioethics projects centered around my Tribe. My responsibilities have included literature review, qualitative coding, and manuscript preparation, as well as assisting with curriculum and materials for community-facing educational outreach. This work gave me experience in community-based participatory research, Tribal policy, and approaches that center Indigenous sovereignty and relational accountability in genomic science.



Summer Intern and Post-Bac Fellow
Sara Chandros Hull, PhD
National Institutes of Health, National Human Genome Research Institute, Tribal Health Research Office
With Dr. Hull and the Tribal Health Research Office at the NIH, I gained experience in how literature research supports broader projects focused on the ethics and governance of Tribal health research within U.S. federal government. My work has involved background research on policy and guidance documents, training in Institutional Review Board meetings, and contributions to public presentations and manuscripts. These experiences have given me a foundational view of how federal structures are trying to address Tribal priorities in health research, and how ethics can help push those structures toward respecting Tribal sovereignty.
